content.text:
A rocket is shot from the top of a tower at an angle of 45° above the horizontal (Fig. 19-1). It hits the ground in 5 seconds at a horizontal distance from the foot of the tower equal to three times the height of the tower. Find the height of the tower.<image 1>

A. h = 100 ft
B. h = 80 ft
C. h = 110 ft
D. h = 85 ft

To find the height of the tower, we can use the given information and the principles of projectile motion. The rocket is shot at an angle of 45° and hits the ground in 5 seconds at a horizontal distance of three times the height of the tower.

Given:
- Horizontal distance (x = 3h
- Time of flight, t = 5 seconds
- Angle of projection, θ = 45°

The horizontal distance (x can be expressed using the horizontal component of the initial velocity (v_x and the time of flight t:
\[ x = v_x \cdot t \]

The horizontal component of the initial velocity \( v_x \) can be found using the angle of projection:
\[ v_x = v \cdot \cos(45°) \]
\[ v_x = v \cdot \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2 \]

The vertical component of the initial velocity \( v_y \) can be found using the angle of projection:
\[ v_y = v \cdot \sin(45°) \]
\[ v_y = v \cdot \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \]

The vertical displacement (y ( which is the height of the tower h, can be found using the vertical component of the initial velocity and the time time of flight:
\[ y = v_y \cdot t - \frac{1}{2} g t^2 \]
\[ y = \left( v \cdot \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \right) \cdot t - \frac{1}{2} g t^2 \]

Substituting the given values:
\[ y = \left( v \cdot \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \right) \cdot 5 - \frac{1}{2} g ( 5^2 \]
\[ y = \left( v \cdot \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \right) \cdot 5 - \frac{1}{2} g \cdot 25 \]
\[ y = \left( v \cdot \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \right) \cdot 5 - \frac{25}{2} g \]

Since the horizontal distance x is three times the height of the tower:
\[ x = 3h \]
\[ 3h = v_x \cdot t \]
\[ 3h = \left( v \cdot \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \right) \cdot 5 \]
\[ 3h = \left( v \cdot \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \right) \cdot 5 \]
\[ 3h = \left( v \cdot \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \right) \cdot 5 \]

Substituting the value of y ( which is the height of the tower h:
\[ h = \left( v \cdot \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \right) \cdot 5 - \frac{25}{2} g \]

Solving for h:
\[ h = \left( v \cdot \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \right) \cdot 5 - \frac{25}{2} g \]
\[ h = \left( v \cdot \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \right) \cdot 5 - \frac{25}{2} g \]

Substituting the given values:
\[ h = \left( v \cdot \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \right) \cdot 5 - \frac{25}{2} g \]
\[ h = \left( v \cdot \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \right) \cdot 5 - \frac{25}{2} g \]

Solving for h:
\[ h = \left( v \cdot \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \right) \cdot 5 - \frac{25}{2} g \]
\[ h = \left( v \cdot \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \right) \cdot 5 - \frac{25}{2} g \]

Substituting the given values:
\[ h = \left( v \cdot \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \right) \cdot 5 - \frac{25}{2} g \]
\[ h = \left( v \cdot \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \right) \cdot 5 - \frac{25}{2} g \]
